title: Świętoszów
text:
Świętoszów (; ) is a village in the administrative district of <a href="Gmina%20Osiecznica">Gmina Osiecznica</a>, within <a href="Boles%C5%82awiec%20County">Bolesławiec County</a>, <a href="Lower%20Silesian%20Voivodeship">Lower Silesian Voivodeship</a>, in south-western <a href="Poland">Poland</a> in the <a href="Lower%20Silesian%20Wilderness">Lower Silesian Wilderness</a>, on the river <a href="Kwisa">Kwisa</a>.
It lies approximately north of <a href="Osiecznica%2C%20Lower%20Silesian%20Voivodeship">Osiecznica</a>, north-west of <a href="Boles%C5%82awiec">Bolesławiec</a>, and west of the regional capital - <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a>.
History.
In the <a href="Early%20Middle%20Ages">Early Middle Ages</a> the region was inhabited by the <a href="Bobrzanie">Bobrzanie</a> tribe, one of the <a href="Slavs">Slavic</a> <a href="Lechites">Lechitic</a> tribes, and it became part of the emerging Polish state under its first historic ruler <a href="Mieszko%20I">Mieszko I</a> in the 10th century. Probably in the 14th century a <a href="forge">forge</a> was established at the site of the village, however the village itself was founded after 1550.
In the 1898 the <a href="German%20Army%20%28German%20Empire%29">German Army</a> created a very large training ground here. In <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> it was the site of a large <a href="prisoner-of-war%20camp">prisoner-of-war camp</a> for <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n soldiers. After 1919, <a href="Poles">Polish</a> <a href="Silesian%20Uprisings">Silesian insurgents</a> were held in the camp. In 1941 the <a href="Bergmann%20Battalion">Bergmann Battalion</a> and <a href="Nachtigall%20Battalion">Nachtigall Battalion</a> trained in Neuhammer. In <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> another POW camp <a href="Stalag%20VIII-E">Stalag VIII-E</a> was built here, to house <a href="Poland">Polish</a> and <a href="France">French</a> prisoners. In 1942 they were replaced with <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> prisoners, and the camp was placed under the administration of <a href="Stalag%20VIII-C">Stalag VIII-C</a> near Żagań. At least 50,000 Soviet prisoners died here from disease, starvation and inhumane treatment, the last 200 of them killed as traitors after the war by the <a href="NKVD">NKVD</a>. A <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> base until 1992, today it is the site of a <a href="Polish%20Armed%20Forces">Polish Army</a> base, and since January 2017 also the <a href="NATO">NATO</a> forces.
Sports.
The local <a href="Association%20football">football</a> club is Twardy Świętoszów, which competes in the lower leagues, reaching the <a href="III%20liga">III liga</a> (fourth tier) in 2010.
